title.narrative: PRIDE / Asia

description.narrative: Working towards diverse and inclusive societies in which LGBTI are able to participate to their full potential in some countries in the Asian region.

activity-date.narrative: Empowered LGBTI: Many individuals are empowered by activities of community based groups, e.g. regular gatherings, camps, SOGIESC and human rights trainings, movie screenings and discussions, sports activities (e.g. badminton) in combination with infotainment sessions, and workshops on different topics, e.g. how to manage personal finances. Also other stakeholders were reached out to and sensitized, such as students, women football players, visitors of film festival, parents of LGBTI; many of them met other LGBTI for the first time and some of them came out themselves. Methods used: infotainment events, online photo project, exhibitions, meetings in school settings, sports, arts events, and setting up Gay Straight Alliances in universities. These interventions contribute to individual LGBTI taking action and leaders in society being supportive of LGBTI people within their community. Strong LGBTI community: Furthermore front liners are identified, e.g. in transmen communities, and their leadership skills are being developed to mobilize them into activism. Methods used: trans school for young trans women, rainbow camp for LGBT community. These interventions directly feed into motivating individual LGBTI to accept themselves more and start taking action, and an increased number of people becoming volunteers and taking community initiative. Next to these developments the social support system is being strengthened as crucial coping mechanism, gathering community members for community events where they spend a good time, are being informed and feel part of a community. Capable CBO: The resource centers have built the capacities of their members or partners, ensuring that they represent and value their constituency, and that needs of LGBTI are identified and prioritized. These trainings are on PME, leadership development, strategy planning, development of statutes, and other skills. An example is the ‘LBQ academy’ to develop new LBQ leadership based on feminist principles. Established organisations that also serve as fiscal sponsor develop new methods on community mapping, context analysis, drafting and implementing a community driven advocacy policy and new models for (technically) supporting LGBTI initiative groups. Also COC has organized an Appreciative Leadership workshop for 16 partners in a country, resulting in communication skills building of individual participants, increase of mutual respect and understanding, development of capacities of partners and strengthening the movement. Mobilised LGBTI movement: On a national advocacy level mainstream CSOs have taken initiative to have influence on the development of implementing Transgender laws and medical procedures and Labor codes. They ensure participation of LGBTI community based initiatives. In other countries the LGBTI CSOs have taken initiative to lobby against discriminatory or even criminalizing legislation as part of a broad coalition. COC has invested in a ‘mobilized LGBTI movement’ by organizing annual national meetings and workshops for both PRIDE and Bridging the Gaps partners that do not interact on a regular basis: LGBTI human rights based organisations and groups and HIV/AIDS focused organisations and groups targeting MSM and transwomen. Thus LGBTI organisations (including MSM and transwomen organisations) are connected and exchange information on their respective remits, thus shaping the national movement. The Netherlands Embassies in-country support the LGBTI movement by coordinating and consulting with LGBTI organisations and COC and aligning with other embassies (with focus on member states of the Global Equality Coalition), to coordinate diplomatic advocacy strategies aiming to improve for example non-discrimination and equality legislation and policies and their execution, and to counteract discriminatory and criminalizing legislation, protecting the rights of LGBTI. At the regional level network organisations operating independently and interacting on an ad hoc basis met for 3 days in October 2017. At the meeting where all networks and COC shared responsibility for the process (co-facilitation) and outcome, they got acquainted, identified gaps and opportunities and developed the rough outline of a joint regional proposal. The regional LGBTI movement is being shaped, consisting of networks that are all complementary to one another, with focus on LGBTI in Asia; HIV/AIDS (MSM & transwomen); LGBTI in relation to advocacy, ASEAN and capacity building; sexual and bodily rights; transgender people. The joint project for 2018 on well-being of activists and organisations has recently started. Global HR movement: Several key activists have gained skills and tools to lobby and advocate internationally. COC has facilitated and supported the LGBTI movement in the international arena, creating access to international human rights mechanisms, such as the UPR and CEDAW so they can engage with human rights mechanisms effectively. In one of the program countries the Dutch embassy facilitated a meeting for community leaders to present their UPR report to diplomatic representatives from member states of the Equal Rights Coalition.

title.narrative: 2018 Q2 IATI PRIDE SSEA
Capable Community Based Organisations.

description.narrative: Capable LGBTI organisations are essential in terms of supporting individual LGBTI people, giving a voice to the LGBTI community and aligning with different players in the broader LGBTI movement. They need to function at an “operational minimum” before they can start doing advocacy effectively.

title.narrative: DD5 DD5: Number of CBOs improving their capacities under PRIDE.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. This indicator measures all unique organisations who underwent a training on organisational development, financial management, L&A and/or were supported to attend events or conferences where they built on their skills through participation and engagement. Note that this indicator also counts those organisations not funded by PRIDE but are trained by partners in-country.

comment.narrative: 157 organisations improved their capacities under pride.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on sustainable revenue streams.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their financial management capabilities. These skills have been developed through trainings on organisational finances, fundraising, auditing, bookkeeping. This indicator also counts those organisations who have been successful in obtaining additional funds through the help of COC.

comment.narrative: 30 organisations underwent capacity development on financial mgmt of which 11 were able to secure additional independent funding for future work.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on governance and leadership skills.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their governance and leadership skills. These skills have been developed through trainings on organisational management, statutes, codes of conduct, communications and branding.

comment.narrative: 30 CBOs participated in a 3 day strategy workshop and meeting to share experience and discuss next steps for the movement. Through activities, some members identified their problems in their activities. This result was collected through observation by trainers and project staff and through evaluation sheet by participants. in total in the region, through these mechanisms 124 organisations were trained on governance and leadership skills.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on lobby and advocacy strategies.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their lobby and advocacy strategies. These strategies have been developed through trainings on advocacy tactics, lobbying methods etc.

comment.narrative: 68 organisations were part of L&A skills development in 2018 in the region.

title.narrative: DD6 DD6: Number of CBOs participating in PRIDE.

description.narrative: This indicator measures all partners under PRIDE for the given year.

title.narrative: Mobilised LGBTI Movement.

description.narrative: LGBTI organisations need to cooperate to reach their joint goals, while also respecting their diversity. Change starts when they connect, begin exchanging information and become a mobilised LGBTI movement. It is when they are linked to non-LGBTI stakeholders and to broader civil society organisations that change becomes possible in society.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of advocacy initiatives carried out by grassroots organisations, community based organisations and CSOs to improve, change or influence relevant laws, policies and/or societal norms.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices etc. These initiatives are held with various stakeholders (religious leaders, service providers, schools, police, local governments and ministries). The aim of these dialogues is to sensitise the targeted actors on LGBTI and SOGIESC issues, and change/improve or influence their actions. Through this indicator, we measure how many such initiatives have been undertaken. This indicator does not encompass advocacy activities carried out at international spaces such as the UN, UPR etc. but only in-country/regional level engagement.

comment.narrative: In SSEA in 2018, 77 advocacy initiatives were undertaken where the strongest focus was paid towards media advocacy. 35 initiatives targeting media actors using media sources were undertaken and a public initiative video aimed at public opinion on transgender people, reaching almost 2 million people in the region. TV channels in one country in the region were sensitised on objective reporting and using social media influencers in another country was a tactic used to reach young people. The targeting of family members in the region was also one that got attention through series of workshops designed for the families of LGBTI, support groups and interventions in schools. In another country, the main focus of community advocacy was targeted at labour unions.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of times unique alliances between different organisations were formed.

description.narrative: Grassroots organisations, CBOs and other CSOs come together for multiple reasons in order to cooperate and/or align efforts with broader movements - human rights, LGBTI, women's rights, etc. In some instances these cooperations manifest in the way of joint pressure campaigns on governments and research undertakings or through network expansion in remote areas of the country. For the LGBTI movement this helps build and grow a base of allies outside the community and also to increase visibility and develop solidarity with cross-cutting intersectional issues. This indicator measures the number of times unique alliances of two or more partners other relevant organisations and/or actors were formed.

comment.narrative: 13 alliances with different movements were formed in 2018, including collaboration with legal aid institutions, schools, health workers and labour unions.

title.narrative: DD3 DD3: Number of targeted actors adopting LGBTI and SOGIESC friendly terminology, rhetoric and framing.

description.narrative: On the basis of the initiatives carried out under indicator 10, this indicator measures successful adoption of terminology, rhetoric and framing on LGBTI/SOGIESC issues by those targeted.

comment.narrative: From the 70 advocacy initiatives undertaken in 2018, 110 actors displayed a change in their behaviour and attitudes towards LGBTI friendly rhetoric. The acceptance of name changes for Trans people in one community paved the way for future LGBTI-friendliness as well and film screenings served as a great source to influence opinions. Similarly the bringing of lawyers on board as legal aid institutions refuse to give assistance to LGBTI people act as a great help in crisis and emergencies.

title.narrative: Empowered LGBTI Individuals

description.narrative: Social change starts with individual LGBTI people who no longer accept being marginalised but decide to take action. Individual stories raise public awareness and expose the level of exclusion in society. Empowered LGBTI individuals serve as role models for others, and their actions form important steps in the creation of LGBTI communities.

title.narrative: Number of LGBTI and allies, community members, service deliverers, and/or leaders educated and sensitised on LGBTI issues, who can carry forward the messages further.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices, self-esteem and acceptance etc. Through this indicator, we measure how many people have been reached through these initiatives.

comment.narrative: 2790 people were reached through the advocacy and other community events in the region. Using public film screenings, different social events such as baking classes and hub cafe events were used to build community mobilisation masses.

title.narrative: Number of knowledge dissemination activities taken on to bring the LGBTI community together, sensitise and inform them on their legal rights, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression and sex characteristics.

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of knowledge dissemination tools (eg. legal handbooks) created and distributed, activities held (eg. soccer games, cooking classes etc.) amongst the community to inform, sensitise and/or educate them on relevant issues. These activities can be under the pretext of self-esteem building, empowerment trainings and the tools serve the purpose of awareness raising and information sharing within the community.

comment.narrative: The start of a resource centre, with events organised there for community gathering, skills building sessions for community members, a handbook on legal guides for LGBTI worker

title.narrative: Number of promotional actions undertaken by organisations to reach their constituency.

description.narrative: Promotions of their events, flyers of their organisations etc. are counted as promotional actions. These actions are solely undertaken to inform the community of the presence of the organisation.

title.narrative: Strong LGBTI Communities.

description.narrative: Strong communities start when front liners take action and bring individuals together. Communities start as small-scale social events and are often based on positive drivers: contact, entertainment or a shared interest. Creating a safe space is essential in starting communities.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of crisis response measures taken up.

description.narrative: At certain unfortunate moments, there arises a need for emergency and crisis response measures to be taken up by the LGBTI community in countries. These responses, while not a planned intervention under PRIDE, are supported by COC with the goal of building resilience within the community and extending solidarity in dire times of need. These responses include public statements issued, back-door diplomacy with embassies on the ground, emergency shelter provision, legal-aid services, medical and psychological help and provision of basic services such as food and water. Through this indicator we measure the number of such responses that have been deployed both by COC and its partners.

comment.narrative: 56 cases access the counseling services: • 3 face to face counseling for parents • 53 counseling cases for WLW and other GBT people via chat window on the website of WLW There is a variety of issues that were supported, such as: being forced to meet futurefortune-tellers, being hit, being isolated, being scolded and forced to get married, being suffering from violence by their husbands or partners’ families, being separated from their children; and coming out  498 calls of LGBT people approached the counseling hotline:  672 cases approached counseling chat service on CSAGA website - 85 cases are supported with legal support services

title.narrative: Number of events the LGBTI community hosted/participated in.

description.narrative: Using public spaces to raise awareness and visibility of LGBTI issues is an effective way to mobilise, build communities and make public statements. Being visible publicly in many countries is in itself a significant achievement due to threats posed by social and political climates. This indicator measures the number of times the LGBTI community was supported in being publicly visible through events such as Pride, IDAHOT, Women's Day, Carnival etc.

comment.narrative: 23 public events hosted and participated in in 2018.

title.narrative: Number of safe spaces created.

description.narrative: Physical shelter creation in-country for LGBTI individuals to gather, exchange and/or seek safety.
